qas.question: What are the names of the two states that are sovereign in the British Isles today?

answers.text: Ireland and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

qas.question: What is another name that Ireland is also called?
Northern Ireland is part of which country?

answers.text: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

qas.question: What is another name for the  United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland?
Which three states in the United Kingdom have devolved governements?
The Republic of Channel Islands refers to which country?
Ireland is made up of how many constituent parts?

plausible_answers.text: Wales, forming Great Britain, and Northern Ireland

qas.question: The four constituent parts of the United Kingdom are: England, Wales, Spain and what other country?
The Isle of Man and what else are known as the United Kingdom?
For legislative purposes, Scotland, Southern Ireland, England and Wales form what?

context: There are two sovereign states in the isles: <a0_0>Ireland and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland<a0_0/>. <b5_0>Ireland<b5_0/>, sometimes called the <a1_0>Republic of Ireland<a1_0/>, governs five sixths of the island of Ireland, with the remainder of the island forming Northern Ireland. Northern Ireland is a part of the <a2_0>United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland<a2_0/>, usually shortened to simply the <a3_0>United Kingdom<a3_0/>, which governs the remainder of the archipelago with the exception of the Isle of Man and the Channel Islands. The Isle of Man and the two states of the Channel Islands, <b8_0>Jersey and Guernsey<b8_0/>, are known as the Crown Dependencies. They exercise constitutional rights of self-government and judicial independence; responsibility for international representation rests largely upon the UK (in consultation with the respective governments); and responsibility for defence is reserved by the UK. The United Kingdom is made up of <b6_0>four<b6_0/> constituent parts: England, Scotland and <b7_0>Wales, forming Great Britain, and Northern Ireland<b7_0/> in the north-east of the island of Ireland. Of these, <a4_0>Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland<a4_0/> have "devolved" governments meaning that they have their own parliaments/assemblies and are self-governing with respect to certain areas set down by law. For judicial purposes, Scotland, Northern Ireland and England and Wales (the latter being one entity) form <b9_0>separate legal jurisdiction<b9_0/>, with there being no single law for the UK as a whole.
